climbs.name: Hells Lake Falls
climbs.fa: David Jones, Nick Jones, and Bill Noble, January 1991

content.description:
Classic, steep, and (almost) roadside ice. What more do you want? If it's in, the route will be obvious from the highway across the small lake. 

Walk across the lake for 100 meters if it's frozen solid, and scramble up the hillside for 15 meters to the base of the route. A small initial step gives way to about 15 meters of steep climbing which eases off near the top.

There are trees about 5-8 meters back from the lip of the ice you can anchor off of to bring up a second, or set up a top rope in good ice at the lip.



If you're nice and ask you should be able to park somewhere at the Haig Inspection Station (63620 Lougheed Hwy., Hope, BC V0X 1L3) and walk across the tracks down to the lake, which is strangely enough called Devils Lake despite the route name being Hells Lake Falls...

Standard ice rack.

This sub-area is for all of the various ice routes littered along Highway 7 between Agassiz and Hope with the exception of the Tailwind area which has it's own dedicated sub-area due to the concentration of routes in there. 
  
 Descriptions for location of each route can be found under the route entry.
